title: Digital Innovation and Neuroscience-Based Mathematics Instructional Design Competency Enhancement Program

context.prior_knowledge: Foundational educational design theories, experience with digital tools, knowledge of mathematics curriculum (functions, geometry, statistics, probability, equations, etc.), understanding of basic teaching methodologies, and graph interpretation skills
context.additional_context: A collaborative learning environment centered on mathematics, supported by digitally equipped classrooms (tablets, interactive whiteboards) and online learning platforms (Khan Academy, etc.). Particularly enables the use of geometric visualization tools (GeoGebra, etc.) and statistical analysis software (SPSS, Excel), with digital whiteboard collaboration features for proof processes.

learning_goals: Developing the ability to design mathematics instruction that visualizes concepts and solves equations and functions using digital tools (interactive content, AI-based analytics, etc.) in blended learning environments

Developing three or more mathematics teaching strategies based on neuroscience-driven learning principles (attention, working memory, executive function, emotional regulation) (e.g., step-by-step equation-solving strategies based on cognitive load theory, graph pattern recognition training, working memory optimization strategies for statistical data interpretation)

Collaboratively producing two or more mathematics curriculum improvement proposals through a Professional Learning Community (PLC) cooperative design process (e.g., enhancing graph transformation activities when reorganizing function units, adding visualization steps to geometric proof processes)

Designing and implementing a learner-adaptive feedback system by analyzing formative assessment data (quizzes, observation records, etc.) (e.g., applying algorithms for analyzing individual error patterns, building a database of common error types in probability problem-solving)
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
